awd_titl_txt: A Terrestrial Perspective of Last Millennium Hydroclimate Variability in the Central Tropical Pacific
awd_abstract_narration:
The tropical Pacific plays an enormous role in shaping global climate patterns, yet our understanding of how tropical Pacific climate has varied in the past remains uncertain due to sparse observations across this vast region. This research project will use lake sediments to reveal changes in precipitation and evaporation on the central tropical Pacific island of Kiritimati during the last 1000 years.  The outcomes of this project will provide insight into the nature of multidecadal to centennial tropical Pacific climate variability, timescales critical in the context of future climate trends.

The proposed research will produce new proxy records of central tropical Pacific climate. Time series of elemental abundance, biological indicators of lake water conductivity, and stable oxygen isotope ratios of ostracod calcium carbonate spanning the last millennium will provide a multi-proxy perspective on past lake water balance and atmospheric moisture balance. In addition, new weather, limnologic and stable oxygen isotope measurements of lake and groundwater will promote a more quantitative understanding of the climate controls on lake water balance within the framework of a proxy system model for lake water and ostracod oxygen isotope ratios. These newly developed records will permit hypothesis testing of whether meridional or zonal changes in atmospheric circulation played a more prominent role in controlling spatial patterns of tropical Pacific hydroclimate variability.

por.por_cntn:
During the last 1000 years, the climate of the tropical Pacific has varied on a range of timescales, from year-to-year to periods of decades and centuries. These changes were large and may have involve latitudinal reversals and longitudinal shifts in temperature, pressure, and precipitation across the tropical Pacific basin. These large-scale reorganizations of the tropical Pacific may have had impacts on weather, climate, ecology, and human societies around the world.

Given the outsized influence of tropical Pacific climate on many aspects of the climate around the world, it is often implicated as the main cause of past changes in climate interpreted from paleoclimate proxy records in many regions. However, the role of the tropical Pacific in driving past climate change is complicated by a lack of agreement among tropical Pacific paleoclimate records regarding the direction, amplitude, and cause of past changes. For example, many records support east-west changes in temperature, pressure, and precipitation, arguing that these represent long-term shifts in the strength of the zonal Walker Circulation. At the same time, past changes interpreted from other paleoclimate records have been interpreted in terms of north-south shifts in the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ), a band of high precipitation that spans the Pacific basin as well as the globe, and is intimately connected to many monsoon systems. Either of these shifts would have major implications for drought, flooding and temperature variability worldwide.

This proposal sought to test these two hypotheses regarding the nature of tropical Pacific climate change over the last 1000 years, focusing on the central tropical Pacific Basin. Here, far removed from continental monsoonal influences, the ITCZ moves seasonally between tropical northern latitudes, while staying north of 2°N. Changes in east-west Walker Circulation also occur here on interannual timescales associated with the El Niño-Southern Oscillation. This region is thus ideal to investigate whether multidecadal to centennial changes in the location of the ITCZ or the strength of the Walker Circulation occurred over the last 1000 years.

 

To test these hypotheses, we generated new paleoclimate records from lake sediments taken from  the coral atoll of Kiritimati, Republic of Kiribati (2°N, 157°W). These records, coupled with an existing paleoclimate record from the nearby, northerly Washington (4.7°N, 160°W) permit us to test a popular hypothesis, that the ITCZ shifted southward during a time period known as the Little Ice Age (1400-1850 CE). Such a shift would have had global climate impacts, and would be manifested as a period of aridity on Washington Island and a period of greater rainfall on Kiritimati. However, if changes in Walker Circulation strength were the primary driver of past tropical Pacific climate changes, both sites would experience aridity (in the case of stronger Walker Circulation) or enhanced precipitation (in the case of weaker Walker Circulation) during the Little Ice Age, or other multidecadal to century time periods over the last 1000 years.

 

Two field seasons in Kiritimati produced a well-dated, last millennium record from ‘Lake 30.’ The interpretation of this record was well-vetted with field hydrologic monitoring data and a robust understanding of lacustrine sedimentation processes. This lake, along with many others across the atoll, freshens and expands after periods of high rainfall, usually related to El Niño events and associated weaker Walker Circulation. The sediment core mineralogy indicated a period of prolonged aridity, resulting in precipitation of the evaporite mineral gypsum, from 960-1030 CE. The sediment mineralogy also suggested the last several decades of the 20th and 21st centuries were relatively wetter on average than the last millennium given that recent sediment is high-Mg calcite, a mineral primarily found in brackish lakes on Kiritimati. Stable hydrogen isotope values from extracted lipids in the sediment agreed with the mineralogy record and more importantly, provided a means to quantitatively reconstruct lake salinity. Overall, this lake was hypersaline throughout much of the last millennium, including a prolonged period of high salinity from 960-1030 CE, as well as shorter episodes of hypersalinity and inferred aridity from 1030-1370 CE.  Extensive radiocarbon dating also indicated the lake dried up completely around 1370 CE.

 

Most significantly, the changes observed in the Lake 30 record are coeval with the timing of changes in inferred aridity from a lake sediment core taken from Washington Island. Thus, this study finds no evidence of a southward shift in the ITCZ over the latitudes of these two islands, and supports a role for Walker Circulation in driving these changes—namely, much stronger Walker Circulation during long intervals of the last millennium.

 

This project supported an early-career female professor and trained three female graduate students. The broader impacts associated with this work included developing and implementing a teaching module on water chemistry and water quality with English Language Learner high school science students at Urbana High School.
